revisions.rev:
{{Feminism sidebar |History}}
'''First-wave feminism''' refers to a period of [[feminist]] activity during the 19th and early twentieth century throughout the world, particularly in the [[United Kingdom]], [[Canada]], the [[Netherlands]] and the [[United States]]. It focused on ''[[de jure]]'' (officially mandated) inequalities, primarily on gaining [[women's suffrage]] (the right to vote).
The term ''first-wave'' was coined in the 1970s.{{by whom|date=March 2013}} The women's movement of that time, with its focus on ''[[de facto]]'' (unofficial) inequalities, acknowledged its predecessors by calling itself ''[[second-wave feminism]]''.
==Origins== {{Main|History of feminism|Protofeminism}} According to Miriam Schneir, [[Simone de Beauvoir]] wrote that the first woman to "take up her pen in defense of her sex" was [[Christine de Pizan]] in the 15th century.<ref name=Schneir-1994>{{cite book|author=Schneir, Miram|title=Feminism: The Essential Historical Writings|year=1994|first=1972|publisher=Vintage Books|page=xiv|isbn=0-679-75381-8}}</ref> [[Heinrich Cornelius Agrippa]] and [[Modesta di Pozzo di Forzi]] worked in the 16th century.<ref name=Schneir-1994 /> [[Marie de Gournay|Marie Le Jars de Gournay]], [[Anne Bradstreet]] and [[François Poullain de la Barre]] wrote in the 17th.<ref name=Schneir-1994 />
[[Mary Wollstonecraft]] published one of the first feminist treatises, ''[[A Vindication of the Rights of Woman]]'' (1792), in which she advocated the social and moral equality of the sexes, extending the work of her 1790 pamphlet, ''[[A Vindication of the Rights of Men]]''. Her later unfinished novel, ''[[Maria: or, The Wrongs of Woman|Maria, or the Wrongs of Woman]]'', earned her considerable criticism as she discussed women's sexual desires. She died young, and her widower, the philosopher [[William Godwin]], quickly wrote a memoir of her that, contrary to his intentions, destroyed her reputation for generations.
Wollstonecraft is regarded as the [[Feminist history in the United Kingdom|grandmother of British feminism]] and her ideas shaped the thinking of the [[suffragette]]s, who campaigned for the women's vote. After generations of work, this was eventually granted − to some women in 1918, and equally with men in 1928.
[[File:8marta.jpg|thumb|upright|right|A 1932 Soviet poster for [[International Women's Day]].]]
[[File:Louise Weiss.jpg|thumb|right|[[Louise Weiss]] along with other Parisian suffragettes in 1935. The newspaper headline reads, in translation, "THE FRENCHWOMAN MUST VOTE".]]
== United Kingdom ==
In 1918 [[Marie Stopes]], who believed in equality in marriage and the importance of women's sexual desire, published ''[[Married Love]]'',<ref name="google2004">{{cite book|author=Stopes, Marie Carmichael and McKibbin, Ross (ed.)|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=M13Q0aymFJoC|title=Married love|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=0-19-280432-4|year=2004|first=1918}}</ref> a sex manual that, according to a survey of American academics in 1935, was one of the 25 most influential books of the previous 50 years, ahead of ''[[Special relativity|Relativity]]'' by [[Albert Einstein]] and ''[[The Interpretation of Dreams]]'' by [[Sigmund Freud]].<ref name="autogenerated811">{{cite journal|doi=10.1098/rstb.2005.1781|author=Short, R.V.|date=August 23, 2005|title=New ways of preventing HIV infection: thinking simply, simply thinking|journal=Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society B: Biological Sciences|volume=361|issue=1469|pages=811–20|publisher=The Royal Society via PubMed (U.S. National Institutes of Health)|pmid=16627296|pmc=1609406}}</ref> The right to vote was granted to some UK women in 1918, and equally with men in 1928.
===Early 20th century===
During the early 20th century, English women achieved civil equality, in theory. [[World War I]] saw more women go to work outside the home. In the beginning of the 20th century, women were limited to factory labor and domestic work. Women gained the right to sit in parliament, although it was only slowly that women were actually elected. Women started serving on school boards and local bodies, and numbers kept increasing after the war. This period also saw more women starting to become more educated. In 1910, "women were attending many leading medical schools, and in 1915 the American Medical Association began to admit women members."<ref name="autogenerated1995">[http://www.wic.org/misc/history.htm, "Women's History in America"], Excerpted from Compton's Interactive Encyclopedia, 1995</ref> The [[Representation of the People Act 1918]] had given women the right to vote if they were property holders and older than 29. In 1928, this was extended to all women over 21.<ref>{{cite book |author=Phillips, Melanie |title=The Ascent of Woman: A History of the Suffragette Movement and the Ideas Behind It |year=2004 |publisher=Abacus |location=London |isbn=978-0-349-11660-0}}</ref> The Sex Disqualification (removal) Act 1919 opened professions and the Civil Service to women, and marriage was no longer seen to stop women from working outside the home legally. A Matrimonial Causes Act in 1923 gave women the right to the same grounds for divorce as men. However, the recession which started in the 1920s meant unemployment rose, which women were the first to face. Many women served in the armed forces during the war. In World War II, around 300,000 American women served in the Navy and Army performing jobs such as secretaries, typists and nurses. Many feminist writers and women's rights activists argued that it was not equality to men which they needed but a recognition of what women need to fulfil their potential of their own natures, not only within the aspect of work but society and home life too. [[Virginia Woolf]] produced her essay ''[[A Room of One's Own]]'' based on the ideas of women as writers and characters in fiction. Woolf said that a woman must have money and a room of her own to be able to write. "[[New Zealand]] was the first country to grant women the right to vote at a national level, while [[Finland]], as well as some American states gave women voting rights at a state level before [[Australia]]n women obtained that right across the nation."<ref name="autogenerated2">{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/ola/citizen/women/women-power.htm#3 |title=Women, Power and The Public Sphere |first=Anita |last=Seibert |first2=Dorota |last2=Roslaniec |publisher=Abc.net.au |date= |accessdate=2012-09-28}}</ref>
== United States == [[Image:Suffragette banner carried in picket of the White House.jpg|thumb|Suffragist with banner, Washington DC, 1918]] ''[[The Great Lawsuit|Woman in the Nineteenth Century]]'' by [[Margaret Fuller]] has been considered the first major feminist work in the United States and is often compared to Wollstonecraft's ''A Vindication of the Rights of Woman''.<ref>Slater, Abby. ''In Search of Margaret Fuller''. New York: Delacorte Press, 1978: 89–90. ISBN 0-440-03944-4</ref> Prominent leaders of the feminist movement in the United States include [[Lucretia Coffin Mott]], [[Elizabeth Cady Stanton]], [[Lucy Stone]], and [[Susan B. Anthony]]; Anthony and other activists such as [[Victoria Woodhull]] and [[Matilda Joslyn Gage]] made attempts to cast votes prior to their legal entitlement to do so, for which many of them faced charges. Other important leaders included several women who dissented against the law in order to have their voices heard,([[Grimké sisters|Sarah and Angelina Grimké]]), in addition to other activists such as [[Carrie Chapman Catt]], [[Alice Paul]], [[Sojourner Truth]], [[Ida B. Wells]], [[Margaret Sanger]] and [[Lucy Burns]].<ref>Dicker, 2008. pp. 28, 47–48.</ref>
First-wave feminism involved a wide range of women, some belonging to [[Christian right|conservative Christian]] groups (such as [[Frances Willard (suffragist)|Frances Willard]] and the [[Woman's Christian Temperance Union]]), others such as [[Matilda Joslyn Gage]] of the [[National Woman Suffrage Association]] (NWSA) resembling the radicalism of much of [[second-wave feminism]]. The majority of first-wave feminists were more moderate and conservative than radical or revolutionary—like the members of the [[American Woman Suffrage Association]] (AWSA) they were willing to work within the political system and they understood the clout of joining with sympathetic men in power to promote the cause of suffrage. The limited membership of the NWSA was narrowly focused on gaining a federal amendment for women's suffrage, whereas the AWSA, with ten times as many members, worked to gain suffrage on a state-by-state level as a necessary precursor to federal suffrage. The NWSA had broad goals, hoping to achieve a more equal social role for women, but the AWSA was aware of the divisive nature of many of those goals and instead chose to focus solely on suffrage. The NWSA was known for having more publicly aggressive tactics (such as picketing and hunger strikes) whereas the AWSA used more traditional strategies like lobbying, delivering speeches, applying political pressure and gathering signatures for petitions.<ref>Dicker, 2008, pp. 40–43.</ref>
The first wave of feminists, in contrast to the second wave, focused very little on the subjects of abortion, birth control, and overall reproductive rights of women. Though she never married, Anthony published her views about marriage, holding that a woman should be allowed to refuse sex with her husband; the American woman had no legal recourse at that time against [[Spousal rape|rape by her husband]].
In 1860, New York passed a revised Married Women's Property Act which gave women shared ownership of their children, allowing them to have a say in their children's wills, wages, and granting them the right to inherit property.<ref name="Dicker, 2008, pp. 30, 38">Dicker, 2008, pp. 30, 38.</ref> Further advances and setbacks were experienced in New York and other states, but with each new win the feminists were able to use it as an example to apply more leverage on unyielding legislative bodies. The end of the first wave is often linked with the passage of the [[Nineteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution]] (1920), granting women the right to vote. This was the major victory of the movement, which also included reforms in [[higher education]], in the workplace and professions, and in health care.
Different accounts of the involvement of African-American women in the Women's Suffrage Movement are given. In a 1974 interview, [[Alice Paul]] notes that a compromise was made between southern groups to have white women march first, then men, then African-American women.<ref name="test">[http://memory.loc.gov/ammem/awhhtml/aw01e/aw01e.html The Library of Congress], 2001.</ref> In another account by the [[National Association for the Advancement of Colored People]] (NAACP), difficulties in segregating women resulted in African-American women marching with their respective States without hindrance.<ref>The Library of Congress, 2001.</ref> Among them was Ida B. Wells-Barnett, who marched with the Illinois delegation.
==Persia== While in some distance in culture and language, the events of the [[Conference of Badasht]] presented progress on the concerns of first wave feminism. There is a synchronicity in time and a likeness in theme and events between Persia (later named Iran) and the United States between the conference at Badasht and the [[Seneca Falls Convention]].<ref>{{cite journal | last = Miller | first =Bradford W. | title =Seneca Falls First Woman’s Rights Convention of 1848; The Sacred Rites of the Nation | journal =Journal of Bahá’í Studies | volume =8 | issue =3 | publisher =Association for Bahá’í Studies |year =1998 | language = |url =http://www.bahai-studies.ca/journal/files/jbs/8.3%20Miller.pdf | accessdate = 4–4–2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite book | last = Penn | first =Michael L. | coauthors =Rahel Nardos | title =Overcoming violence against women and girls: the international campaign to eradicate a worldwide problem | publisher =Rowman & Littlefield | edition =illustrated | year =2003 | pages =1–2 |url =http://books.google.com/books?id=yfpCY3PdpDoC | isbn = 978-0-7425-2500-9 }}</ref> First the conference happened over three weeks from late June to mid-July 1848 and the Seneca Falls Convention happened in mid-July 1848. Both conferences had women ([[Tahirih]] and [[Elizabeth Cady Stanton]]) take strong stances on the role of women in the public arena that some attending reacted to harshly. And lastly leading men present ([[Quddús]] and [[Frederick Douglass]]) supported these calls during the meetings healing the breach. Some even see a parallel in the background discussions that are partially documented to arrange how things would be brought up and settled.
The conference of Badasht is considered by [[Bahá'ís]] as a signal moment that demonstrated that Islamic [[Sharia]] law had been abrogated<ref name="holy">{{Cite book |title = Holy People of the World: A Cross-cultural Encyclopedia | editor-first = Phyllis G. |editor-last = Jestice | year = 2004 | publisher = ABC-CLIO | isbn = 1-57607-355-6| first = Moojan | last=Momen | first2=B. Todd | last2=Lawson | chapter = Tahirih | location = Santa Barbara, CA | ref = harv}}</ref><ref name="maneck">{{cite web | url = http://bahai-library.com/maneck_women_bahai_faith | title = Religion and Women |last = Maneck | first = Susan | location = Albany | publisher = SUNY Press | year = 1994}}</ref> as well as a key demonstration of the thrust of raising the social position of women.<ref name="MM">{{cite journal | last =Momen | first = Moojan | title =The Social Basis of the Babi Upheavals in Iran (1848-53): A Preliminary Analysis |journal =International Journal of Middle East Studies | volume =15 |issue =2 | pages =157–183 | publisher =Cambridge University Press | date = May, 1983 | url =http://www.jstor.org/stable/162988 | jstor =162988 | accessdate = 2012-04-04}}</ref> Although the unveiling led to accusations of immorality<ref> * {{cite book | last =Rev. Wilson | first = Samuel G. | editor-last =Wilder | editor-first =Royal Gould | editor2-last = Pierson|editor2-first =Delavan Leonard| editor3-last =Pierson | editor3-first =Arthur Tappan | editor4-last = Sherwood | editor4-first = James Manning | chapter =Bahaism and the Woman Question - II | chapterurl =http://books.google.com/books?id=nnEJAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA915#v=onepage&q&f=true | title =The Missionary review of the world | publisher =Funk & Wagnalls | volume =37| year = 1914 | pages =915–919 | url =http://books.google.com/books?id=nnEJAQAAMAAJ }}
* {{cite book | last =Rev. Wilson | first = Samuel G. | editor-last = Armstrong | editor-first =William Park | title =The Princeton Theological Review | chapter = The Bayan of the Bab | chapterurl =http://books.google.com/books?id=z_sLAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA633#v=onepage&q&f=true|publisher =MacCalla & Company Inc | volume =13 | year = 1915 | pages = 633–654 | url =http://books.google.com/books?id=z_sLAAAAIAAJ}}
* {{cite book | last =Rev. Wilson | first = Samuel G. | title =Bahaism and Its Claims: A Study of the Religion Promulgated by Baha Ullah and Abdul Baha | publisher =Fleming H. Revell co | year = 1915 | pages =171–172 | url =http://books.google.com/books?id=DHtLAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA171#v=onepage&q&f=true }}</ref><ref name="vaw">{{cite book | last = Milani| first = Farzaneh | title = Veils and words: the emerging voices of Iranian women writers | publisher = I.B.Tauris| series =Contemporary issues in the Middle East| edition = illustrated| year =1992 | pages = 295, esp. 3, 8, 27, 49, 53, 61, 63, 77–82, 90 | url = http://books.google.com/books?id=Z4Iqv2dDySwC&lpg=PR9&pg=PA8#v=onepage&q&f=false| isbn = 978-1-85043-574-7}}</ref> [[the Báb]] responded by supporting her position and naming her ''the Pure'' (Táhirih).<ref name="PSmith">{{cite encyclopedia |last= Smith |first= Peter |encyclopedia= A concise encyclopedia of the Bahá'í Faith |title= Táhirih |year= 2000 |publisher=Oneworld Publications|location= Oxford |isbn= 1-85168-184-1 |pages= 332–333}}</ref> Modern women scholars review this kind of accusation as part of a pattern faced by women leaders and writers then and since<ref> * {{cite book | last = Milani| first = Farzaneh | title = Veils and words: the emerging voices of Iranian women writers | publisher = I.B.Tauris| series =Contemporary issues in the Middle East| edition = illustrated| year =1992 | pages = 295, esp. 3, 8, 27, 49, 53, 61, 63, 77–82, 90 | url = http://books.google.com/books?id=Z4Iqv2dDySwC&lpg=PR9&pg=PA8#v=onepage&q&f=false| isbn = 978-1-85043-574-7}}
* {{cite journal| last = Nafisi | first = Azar | authorlink = Azar Nafisi | title = The Veiled Threat | journal = New Republic | volume = 220| issue = 8 | pages = 24–29| date = February, 1999 | language = | url = | accessdate = }} (at the time Azar Nafisi was a visiting professor at the Johns Hopkins University School of Advanced International Studies.)
* {{cite web | last =Mfon | first = Victoria | coauthors =Elizabeth Selander| title =Azar Nafisi: Voices from the Gaps | work =Artist Pages| publisher = University of Minnesota| date =20–12–2006| url = http://voices.cla.umn.edu/artistpages/nafisiAzar.php|accessdate = 4–2–2012}}
* {{cite journal | last = Zahedi | first = Ashraf | title = Contested Meaning of the Veil and Political Ideologies of Iranian Regimes|journal = Journal of Middle East Women's Studies | volume = 3 | issue = 3 | pages = 75–98 | date = Fall, 2007 | url =http://www.jstor.org/pss/10.2979/MEW.2007.3.3.75| accessdate = 4–2–2012}}
* {{cite journal | last = Shahidian | first = Hammed | title = International trends: Islam, politics, and problems of writing women's history in Iran | journal = Journal of Women's History | volume = 7 | issue = 2 | pages = | date = Summer, 1995 | url = | accessdate =4–2–2012}}</ref> in a way that [[Azar Nafisi]] says "…the Islamic regime today… fears them and feels vulnerable in the face of a resistance that is not just political but existential."<ref>{{cite news | last = Nafisi | first = Azar | authorlink = Azar Nafisi | title = Iran's women: canaries in the coalmine; The battle for emancipation is part of a proud tradition that will shape the future of the regime and Islam itself| newspaper = The Times of London | page = 21 | date = November 27, 2010 | url =http://www.sais-jhu.edu/pressroom/pdf/nafisi_112810.pdf |accessdate = 4–2–2012}}</ref> See the [[Bahá'í Faith and gender equality]].
== Australia == The first wave of Australian feminism, which dates back to the late nineteenth century, was chiefly concerned with suffrage (women's right to vote) and consequently with women's access to parliaments and other political activities.<ref name="autogenerated2"/>
[[Rose Scott]] is an excellent example. In 1882, Scott began to hold a weekly salon in her Sydney home left to her by her late mother. Through these meetings, she became well known amongst politicians, judges, philanthropists, writers and poets. In 1889, she helped to found the Women's Literary Society, which later grew into the Womanhood Suffrage League in 1891. Being left her mother's home, Rose hosted a salon there, leading politicians such as [[Bernhard Ringrose Wise]], [[William Holman]], [[William Morris Hughes]] and [[Thomas Bavin]] met and discussed the drafting of the bill that eventually became the Early Closing Act of 1899.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/legis/nsw/num_act/eca1899n38176.pdf |title=Early Closing Act 1899 No 38 |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2012-09-28}}</ref>
[[File:Tribute to the Suffragettes, close up.jpg|thumb|right|''Tribute to the Suffragettes'' memorial in [[Christchurch]], New Zealand. The figures shown from left to right are [[Amey Daldy]], [[Kate Sheppard]], [[Ada Wells]] and [[Harriet Morison]]]]
== New Zealand == Early New Zealand feminists and suffragettes included [[Maud Pember Reeves]] (Australian-born; later lived in London), [[Kate Sheppard]] and [[Mary Ann Müller]]. In 1893, [[Elizabeth Yates (mayor)|Elizabeth Yates]] became Mayor of [[Onehunga]], the first time such a post had been held by a female anywhere in the [[British Empire]]. Early university graduates were [[Emily Siedeberg]] (doctor, graduated 1895) and [[Ethel Benjamin]] (lawyer, graduated 1897). The Female Law Practitioners Act was passed in 1896 and Benjamin was admitted as a barrister and solicitor of the Supreme Court of New Zealand in 1897. See [[Women's suffrage in New Zealand]].
== Timeline of first-wave feminism worldwide ==
; 1809 * USA, Connecticut: Married women were allowed to execute wills.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://memory.loc.gov/ammem/awhhtml/awlaw3/property_law.html |title=Married Women's Property Laws:Law Library of Congress |publisher=Memory.loc.gov |date= |accessdate=2012-10-31}}</ref> ; 1810 * Sweden: The informal right of an unmarried woman to be declared of [[legal majority]] by royal dispensation was officially confirmed by parliament.<ref>Christine Bladh (Swedish): ''Månglerskor: att sälja från korg och bod i Stockholm 1819–1846'' (1991)</ref> ; 1811 * Austria: Married women were granted separate economy and the right to choose their professions.<ref name="Richard J Evans 1979">Richard J Evans (1979). Kvinnorörelsens historia i Europa, USA, Australien och Nya Zeeland 1840–1920 (The Feminists: Women's Emancipation Movements in Europe, America and Australasia, 1840–1920) Helsingborg: LiberFörlag Stockholm. ISBN 91-38-04920-1 (Swedish)</ref> * Sweden: Married businesswomen were granted the right to make decisions about their own affairs without their husband's consent.<ref>{{cite book|url=http://books.google.se/books?id=rfIfkhOcZ7QC&pg=PA56&dq=kvinnor+n%C3%A4ringslivet+1864&hl=sv&ei=4t_TTob4CZPZ4QSduYTeBg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0CD4Q6AEwAg#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=Mansdominans i förändring: om ledningsgrupper och styrelser : betänkande - Sverige Utredningen om kvinnor pĺ ledande poster i näringslivet - Google Böcker |publisher=Books.google.se |page=56 |isbn=9789138219539 |date= |accessdate=2012-09-28}}</ref> ; 1821 * USA, Maine: Married women were allowed to own and manage property in their own name during the incapacity of their spouse.<ref>[http://mootmagazine.com/2012/08/16/woman-up/]{{dead link|date=October 2012}}</ref> ; 1827 * Brazil: The first elementary schools for girls and the profession of school teacher were opened.<ref>A companion to gender history by: Teresa A. Meade, Merry E. Wiesner-Hanks</ref> ; 1829 * India: [[Sati (practice)|Sati]] was banned.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gktoday.in/abolition-of-sati-by-lord-william-bentinck/ |title=Abolition of Sati by Lord William Bentinck - Indian History - General Knowledge Today |publisher=Gktoday.in |date= |accessdate=2012-10-31}}</ref> * Sweden: Midwives were allowed to use surgical instruments, which were unique in Europe at the time and gave them surgical status.<ref>{{sv icon}} Stig Hadenius, Torbjörn Nilsson & Gunnar Åselius: ''Sveriges historia. Vad varje svensk bör veta'' (''History of Sweden'': "What every Swede should know")</ref> ; 1832 * Brazil: Dionísia Gonçalves Pinto, under the pseudonym [[Nísia Floresta|Nísia Floresta Brasileira Augusta]], published her first book, and the first in Brazil to deal with women's intellectual equality and their capacity and right to be educated and participate in society on an equal basis with men, which was ''Women's rights and men's injustice''. <ref>http://books.google.com/books?id=2nl9p8SOH9gC&pg=PA3&lpg=PA3&dq=nisia+floresta+1832&source=bl&ots=0p2UQx74LV&sig=3YX3wtSbJh7KDvP2XQfGoSsh4do&hl=en&sa=X&ei=p9daUo2VJomQkAft6YCIBg&ved=0CHkQ6AEwDQ#v=onepage&q=%22first%20feminist%22&f=false</ref> It was a translation of ''Woman not Inferior to Man'', often attributed to [[Mary Wortley Montagu]]. <ref>http://books.google.com/books?id=PtyD_4e8gVUC&pg=PA29&lpg=PA29&dq=%22Maria+L%C3%BAcia+Garcia+Pallares-Burke+%22+nisia+floresta&source=bl&ots=GBzJaLgQYH&sig=j7o4DN5bxQXjPj7vGCV0vUDfQD0&hl=en&sa=X&ei=S9ZaUp_IEZCvkAfYsYCIAg&ved=0CCgQ6AEwADgK#v=onepage&q=%22Maria%20L%C3%BAcia%20Garcia%20Pallares-Burke%20%22%20nisia%20floresta&f=false</ref> <ref>http://www.utexas.edu/cola/depts/anthropology/courses/25931</ref> ; 1833 * USA, [[Ohio]]: The first [[co-educational]] American university, [[Oberlin College]], was founded.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www2.northcoast.org/member/oberlin |title=Oberlin College | NCAC: North Coast Athletic Conference |publisher=.northcoast.org |date= |accessdate=2012-10-31}}</ref> * Guatemala: Divorce was legalized; this was rescinded in 1840 and reintroduced in 1894.<ref name="autogenerated3">Women's Roles in Latin America and the Caribbean by Kathryn A. Sloan</ref> ; 1835 * USA, Arkansas: Married women were allowed to own (but not control) property in their own name.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.encyclopediaofarkansas.net/encyclopedia/entry-detail.aspx?entryID=4745 |title=Arkansas Married Woman's Property Law |publisher=Encyclopedia of Arkansas |date=2011-11-18 |accessdate=2012-10-31}}</ref> * Pitcairn Islands: The [[Pitcairn Islands]] granted women the right to vote.<ref>{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=JqCEF9P_O0EC&pg=PT173&lpg=PT173&dq=1839+pitcairn+women+vote&source=bl&ots=u8wIpEj7Cf&sig=C-uFXVLiRDv0RmCjasNvjGFJ0Hg&hl=en&sa=X&ei=yvlmUKKyFerv0gGwjoHoCA&ved=0CDAQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=1839%20pitcairn%20women%20vote&f=false |title=Yes Means Yes!: Visions of Female Sexual Power and A World Without Rape - Jaclyn Friedman, Jessica Valenti - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=2012-10-31}}</ref> ; 1838 * USA, Kentucky: Kentucky gave school suffrage (the right to vote at school meetings) to widows with children of school age.<ref name="google7">{{cite web|url=https://docs.google.com/viewer?a=v&q=cache:zop0OLgJmasJ:faculty.wcas.northwestern.edu/~mdo738/research/Doepke_Tertilt_Voena_1211.pdf+1844+maine+married+women+trade+license&hl=en&gl=us&pid=bl&srcid=ADGEESi1XhOMpToup3xsQkyHWb2bZq5vuE9M4m62gtjJJZzfpNup4goXO025pYR8s6jxVBBruyUKucddtmcGUuZ0_pyjc1grZguLsDb3VNeRc6HDvA3aARutK4Fcg1ERAH-YV8FYUvNh&sig=AHIEtbTyu855NHZdjm8RJLEe9wv91m92tA |title=Powered by Google Docs |publisher=Docs.google.com |date= |accessdate=2012-10-31}}</ref> * USA, Iowa: Iowa was the ﬁrst U.S. state to allow sole custody of a child to its mother in the event of a divorce.<ref name="google7"/> ; 1839 * USA, Mississippi: Mississippi was the ﬁrst U.S. state that gave married women limited property rights.<ref name="google7"/> * Great Britain: The [[Custody of Infants Act 1839]] made it possible for divorced mothers to be granted custody of their children under seven, but only if the Lord Chancellor agreed to it, and only if the mother was of good character.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.historyofwomen.org/custody.html |title=British Women's Emancipation since the Renaissance |publisher=Historyofwomen.org |date= |accessdate=2012-10-31}}</ref> * USA, [[Mississippi]]: The [[Married Women's Property Act 1839]] granted married women the right to own (but not control) property in their own name.<ref>[http://books.google.se/books?id=3mK6xQMF2wQC&pg=PA92&lpg=PA92&dq=Mississippi+Married+women+1839&source=bl&ots=zWcfbt4ppO&sig=xY61RtDJTbMldNcFMhVE7xNeOos&hl=sv&ei=D1TTTsalBsre4QSslYAX&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=9&ved=0CGQQ6AEwCDgK#v=onepage&q=Mississippi%20Married%20women%201839&f=false Janet L. 1916 * Canada: Alberta, Manitoba and Saskatchewan granted women the right to vote.<ref name="scholastic1">{{cite web|author=From Grolier |url=http://teacher.scholastic.com/activities/suffrage/history.htm |title=History of Women's Suffrage | Scholastic.com |publisher=Teacher.scholastic.com |date=1920-08-26 |accessdate=2012-10-31}}</ref> * USA: [[Margaret Sanger]] opened America's first birth control clinic in 1916.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://jwa.org/encyclopedia/article/birth-control-movement-in-united-states |title=Birth Control Movement in the United States | Jewish Women's Archive |publisher=Jwa.org |date= |accessdate=2012-10-31}}</ref> * England: The [[Cat and Mouse Act]] was introduced for suffragettes who refused to eat.<ref name="autogenerated1910"/> ; 1917 * Cuba: Married women were granted separate economy.<ref name="googlecivil"/> * Cuba: Legal majority was granted to married women.<ref name="googlecivil"/> * Netherlands: Women were granted the right to stand for election.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iwdc.org/resources/suffrage.htm |title=International Women's Democracy Center: Women's Suffrage: A Timeline |publisher=Iwdc.org |accessdate=2012-10-31}}</ref> * Mexico: Legal majority for married women.<ref name="googlecivil"/> * Mexico: Divorce was legalized.<ref name="googlecivil"/> * USA, New York: New York granted women the right to vote.<ref name="constitutioncenter1"/> * Belarus: Belarus granted women the right to vote.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://un.by/en/publications/thema/belwomen/19-02-04-4.html |title=Belarusian Women as seen Through an Era |publisher=Un.by |date= |accessdate=2012-10-31}}</ref> * Russia: The [[Russian SFSR]] granted women the right to vote.<ref>{{cite web|author=Articles by Bernstein, L. |url=http://jsh.oxfordjournals.org/content/early/2011/09/29/jsh.shr063.extract |title=Equality & Revolution: Women's Rights in the Russian Empire, 1905–1917. By Rochelle Goldberg Ruthchild (Pittsburgh: University of Pittsburgh Press, 2010. xviii plus 356 pp.) |publisher=Jsh.oxfordjournals.org |date= |accessdate=2012-10-31}}</ref> ; 1918 * Cuba: Divorce was legalized.<ref name="autogenerated3"/> * Russia: The first Constitution of the new Soviet State (the Russian Socialist Federative Soviet Republic) declared that “women have equal rights to men.”<ref>{{cite web|url=https://docs.google.com/viewer?a=v&q=cache:NVfpqOJlVJQJ:apps.americanbar.org/rol/publications/russia-cedaw-eng.pdf+&hl=en&gl=us&pid=bl&srcid=ADGEESj2oV0y6Pwy29rYD8grlVrQFMOp9eWKc9zSyGyxVceV29Z9QeKWrzVhflxszl9yfWAgGH-cG-3v05Ov62Lnq9SiKUQurIZyyHGuH7Xq7nEcvVFtKtF6cN8OfSibULCbd4ynzgz4&sig=AHIEtbTFCJi9G2xZLLXVQ2fOfFu61goluA |title=Powered by Google Docs |publisher=Docs.google.com |date= |accessdate=2012-10-31}}</ref> * Thailand: Universities opened to women.<ref>{{cite book|url=http://books.google.se/books?id=HzTHaIEduwYC&pg=PA98&dq=women+history+universities+Thailand&hl=sv&ei=tJrbTs3_JqX24QSh1PzVDQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=8&sqi=2&ved=0CGIQ6AEwBw#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=Patit Paban Mishra: The history of Thailand |publisher=Books.google.se |page=98 |isbn=978-0-313-34091-8 |date=2010-08-19 |accessdate=2012-09-28}}</ref> * England: In 1918 [[Marie Stopes]], who believed in equality in marriage and the importance of women's sexual desire, published ''[[Married Love]]'',<ref name="google2004"/> a sex manual that, according to a survey of American academics in 1935, was one of the 25 most influential books of the previous 50 years, ahead of ''[[Special relativity|Relativity]]'' by [[Albert Einstein]] and ''[[The Interpretation of Dreams]]'' by [[Sigmund Freud]].<ref name="autogenerated811"/> * USA, Michigan, South Dakota, Oklahoma: Michigan, South Dakota, and Oklahoma granted women the right to vote.<ref name="constitutioncenter1"/> * Austria: Austria granted women the right to vote.<ref name="scholastic1"/> * Canada: Canada granted women the right to vote on the federal level (the last province to enact women's suffrage was Quebec in 1940.)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.elections.ca/content.aspx?section=res&dir=his&document=chap2&lang=e |title=Elections Canada Online | A History of the Vote in Canada |publisher=Elections.ca |date= |accessdate=2012-10-31}}</ref> * United Kingdom: The [[Representation of the People Act]] was passed which allowed women over the age of 30 who met a property qualification to vote. Although 8.5 million women met this criteria, it only represented 40 per cent of the total population of women in the UK. The same act extended the vote to all men over the age of 21.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.parliament.uk/about/living-heritage/transformingsociety/electionsvoting/womenvote/overview/thevote/ |title=Women get the vote - UK Parliament |publisher=Parliament.uk |date=2010-04-21 |accessdate=2012-10-31}}</ref> * United Kingdom: The [[Parliamentary Qualification of Women Act]] was passed allowing women to stand as Members of Parliament.<ref name="autogenerated1910"/> * Czechoslovakia: Czechoslovakia granted women the right to vote.<ref name="scholastic1"/> ; 1919 * Germany: Germany granted women the right to vote.<ref name="scholastic1"/> * Azerbaijan: Azerbaijan granted women the right to vote.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.today.az/news/vdiaspora/87899.html |title=History of Azerbaijani and US women’s rights to vote discussed at US Congress Library |publisher=Today.Az |date= |accessdate=2012-10-31}}</ref> * Italy: Women gained more property rights, including control over their own earnings, and access to some legal positions.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.keele.ac.uk/history/currentundergraduates/tltp/SUFFRAGE/DOCUMENT/FEMITALA.HTM |title=Š The Civil Code of 1865 and the Origins of the Feminist Movement in Italy |publisher=Keele.ac.uk |date= |accessdate=2012-10-31}}</ref> * Great Britain: The [[Sex Disqualification (Removal) Act 1919]] became law. In a broad opening statement it specified that, “[a] person shall not be disqualified by sex or marriage from the exercise of any public function, or from being appointed to or holding any civil or judicial office or post, or from entering or assuming or carrying on any civil profession or vocation”. The Act did provide employment opportunities for individual women and many were appointed as magistrates, but in practice it fell far short of the expectations of the women’s movement. Senior positions in the civil service were still closed to women and they could be excluded from juries if evidence was likely to be too “sensitive”.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.historyextra.com/feature/women-first |title=Women first | BBC History Magazine |publisher=Historyextra.com |date= |accessdate=2012-10-31}}</ref> * Luxembourg: Luxembourg granted women the right to vote.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.db-decision.de/CoRe/Luxembourg.htm |title=European Database: Women in Decision-making | Country Report Luxembourg |publisher=Db-decision.de |date= |accessdate=2012-10-31}}</ref> * Canada: Women were granted the right to be candidates in federal elections.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.elections.ca/res/eim/article_search/article.asp?id=84&lang=e&frmPageSize= |title=Elections Canada On-Line | Electoral Insight |publisher=Elections.ca |date=2010-06-14 |accessdate=2012-10-31}}</ref> * Netherlands: The Netherlands granted women the right to vote. The right to stand in election was granted in 1917.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.db-decision.de/CoRe/Netherlands.htm |title=European Database: Women in Decision-making | Country Report Netherlands |publisher=Db-decision.de |date= |accessdate=2012-10-31}}</ref> * New Zealand: New Zealand allowed women to stand for election into parliament.<ref>{{cite web|author=EC |url=http://www.elections.org.nz/study/education-centre/history/votes-for-women.html |title=Votes for Women | Elections New Zealand |publisher=Elections.org.nz |date=2005-04-13 |accessdate=2012-10-31}}</ref> * England: [[Nancy Astor]] became the first woman to take her seat in the [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom|House of Commons]].<ref name="autogenerated1910"/> ; 1920 * China: The first female students were accepted in [[Peking University]], soon followed by universities all over China.<ref>{{cite book|url=http://books.google.se/books?id=N0ths5DOgGgC&pg=PA737&lpg=PA737&dq=china+beijing+woman+student+1920&source=bl&ots=bV7iSWWVfG&sig=FblBiOG4MWmMdWuU9WuZFa0IJqk&hl=sv&ei=CpevS7muFsm4-QaZtfnmCg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0CBMQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=china%20beijing%20woman%20student%201920&f=false |title=Routledge International Encyclopedia ... – Google Böcker |publisher=Books.google.se |page=737 |isbn=978-0-415-92088-9 |date= |accessdate=2012-09-28}}</ref> * Haiti: The apothecary profession was opened to women.<ref name="haiticulture.ch"/> * Korea: The profession of telephone operator, as well as several other professions, such as store clerks, were opened to women.<ref name="google6"/> * Sweden: Legal majority was granted to married women and equal marriage rights were granted to women.<ref name="Lilla Focus Uppslagsbok 1979"/> * USA: The 19th Amendment was signed into law, granting all American women the right to vote.<ref name="google7"/> * England: [[Oxford University]] opened its degrees to women.<ref name="autogenerated6"/> ; 1921 * England: The [[Six Point Group]] was founded by [[Lady Rhondaa]] to push for women's social, political, occupational, moral, economic, and legal equality.<ref name="autogenerated6"/> ; 1922 * China: [[International Women's Day]] was celebrated in China from 1922 on.<ref>{{cite web|author=Thursday, March 8, 2012 by Jessica Sager |url=http://www.gurl.com/2012/03/08/what-is-international-womens-day-2012/ |title=What Is International Women's Day 2012? Celebrate Women Today! |publisher=Gurl.com |date=2012-03-08 |accessdate=2012-10-31}}</ref> * United Kingdom: The [[Law of Property Act 1922]] was passed, giving wives the right to inherit property equally with their husbands.<ref name="autogenerated6"/> * England: The Infanticide Act was passed, ending the death penalty for women who killed their children if the women's minds were found to be unbalanced.<ref name="autogenerated6"/> ; 1923 * Nicaragua: [[Elba Ochomogo]] became the first woman to obtain a university degree in Nicaragua.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.historia.fcs.ucr.ac.cr/articulos/esp-genero/2parte/CAP12Vicky.htm |title=Josefa Toledo De Aguerri: Her Life And Her Legacy |publisher=Historia.fcs.ucr.ac.cr |date= |accessdate=2012-10-31}}</ref> * England: The Matrimonial Causes Act gave women the right to petition for divorce on the grounds of adultery.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/radio4/womanshour/timeline/1920.shtml |title=BBC Radio 4 - Woman's Hour - Women's History Timeline: 1920 - 1929 |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2012-10-31}}</ref> ; 1925 * UK: The Guardianship of Infants Act gave parents equal claims over their children.<ref name="autogenerated6"/> ; 1928 * UK: The right to vote was granted to all UK women equally with men in 1928.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bl.uk/learning/histcitizen/21cc/struggle/struggle.html |title=The struggle for democracy |publisher=Bl.uk |date=1928-07-02 |accessdate=2012-10-31}}</ref>
